awd_titl_txt: Cocenters and Representations of Reductive p-adic Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
Representation theory is a branch of mathematics that studies symmetries via linear algebra. It is a major mathematical area and is also a very powerful tool in the study of other areas, such as physics and number theory. Weyl groups are special groups of symmetries that consist of product of reflections. The structure and the representations of Weyl groups plays a fundamental role in understanding the structure and the representations of many larger groups, for example the groups of all invertible matrices over finite, real, and complex fields.  An underlying goal of this project is to use some recent discoveries about Weyl groups to study the structure and representations of reductive p-adic groups, that is matrix groups over p-adic fields.  
 
Roughly speaking, the category of representations of a reductive p-adic group is dual to the cocenter of its Hecke algebra. The PI has established the Newton decomposition of the cocenter of this Hecke algebra, based on some recent discoveries about Weyl groups. This research will systematically develop consequences of this decomposition. Results will have applications in many directions in the theory of representations of reductive p-adic groups. More precisely, the PI plans to describe the relationship between the cocenter and the orbital integrals; the relationships between cocenters of different groups arising from base change and inner forms; and the relationships between the cocenter and the mod-l representations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project carried out research in an area of mathematics linking number theory and representation theory, known as the Langlands program. Ultimately, the goal of this program is to gain a deeper understanding of number theory (properties of solutions of particular equations with integers coefficients) using techniques from other areas, such as geometry, analysis, and the theory of Lie groups over local and global fields.

The PI studied objects in the Langlands program, in particular Hecke algebras (their centers and cocenters),  affine Grassmannians, Schubert varieties, and finally Shimura varieties and their local models.

Shimura varieties can be viewed as solution sets of equations with a lot of symmetry, and they are the most important testing ground for Langlands' global reciprocity conjectures.  The PI and his collaborators established some conjectures which specify how the geometric structure of certain Shimura varieties ``modulo a prime p'' can be captured in terms of certain elements in the centers of certain Hecke algebras.  The so-called Haines-Kottwitz Test Function Conjecture was proved essentially in full generalty by the PI together with Timo Richarz. These results were published in 2020 and 2021.

As part of out study of local models of Shimura varieties, we were led to a deeper of study of Schubert varieties of quite general reductuve groups over Laurent series fields of positive characteristic. This led us to discover, with João Lourenço, that ``most'' such Schubert varieties are not normal, when working over ``bad'' positive characteristic Laurent series fields. 

The non-normal Schubert varieties are therefore unavoidable in this area, and it is important to understand the nature of the singularities in their normalizations. The PI studied the singularities of normalized Schubert varieties in connection with local models, leading us to prove that ``most'' Kisin-Pappas integral models of Shimura varieties with parahoric level structure are normal and Cohen-Macaulay, answering in great generality a question which goes back to de Jong (early 1990s). 

 

The PI and Richarz also classified all smooth normalized Schubert varieties in twisted affine Grassmannians, confirming the ``exotic smoothness'' conjecture of Rapoport from around 2010.

In terms of broader impacts, the PI actively involved his PhD students as well as the PhD students of Xuhua He in the themes of this project.  This grant supported the research behind 4 student papers (two of which have appeared, in the J Alg, and IMRN). Two other students of the PI have nearly completed papers, which will acknowledge support of this grant, when they appear.

The PI organizes several seminars at the University of Maryland, as well as the John Hopkins-University of Maryland Algebra and Number Theory Day (twice per year, jointly with Yiannis Sakellaridis of JHU).
